Research Papers

Continuous Gravitational Waves from Gravitars in Quadratic F(R) Modified Gravity

Originally wrote in September 2023

This is a research paper I wrote under Associate Professor and LIGO Collaboration Member Dr. Madeline Wade through the online Pioneer Research Program that’s fully-accredited by Oberlin College. Fortunately, I was on a $6,850 full need/merit-based scholarship. Ranking among the top 131 papers from 1,472 papers, my paper was nominated for the 2023 Pioneer Research Journal.

Do you know electromagnetic waves? Yes, the ones that give you WiFi, Bluetooh, and cell service? Well, there are also gravitional waves! When big objects accelerate, they send out gravitational waves (or GWs for short) that signal, “The gravitational field is changing!” I am sure you have heard that we wouldn’t know for 8 minutes if the sun were to suddenly disappear (which is impossible, but let’s ignore that). That’s because GWs travel at the speed of light, so we wouldn’t notice anything different until the GW saying, “There is no sun anymore!” arrives along with the darkness.

Predcited to exist by Einstein in the early 20th century, GWs were first detected in September 2015 by two merging blackholes (cool, right?). This discovery was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics 2017.

From now on, I’ll simplify some things. Gravitional waves (or GWs for short) can be categorized based on their behavior, one of which being continuous waves that can be emmited by neutron stars. This type of GWs is interesting because it follows a pattern! Unlike other types that appear random, continuous GWs (along with another type, but it’s irrelevant here) follow patterns and are, therefore, detectable… right?
Yes but no. See, they have never been detected (yet) because the world’s best detectors are not sensetive enough (yet). Knowing this, I wanted to study this type of GWs, try to answer why they’re not detectable (yet), compare Einstein’s general relativity, and find some useful constants. So, I simulated our galaxy’s neutron stars twice: first using general relativity then using a modified gravity theory.

I discovered an accurate probability function for the distribution of continues GWs’ strain (i.e., strength) within the galaxy, determined maximum and average values for a certain GW property for galactic CGW-emitting neutron stars, hypothesized reasons for the non-detection of continuous gravitational waves, and showed that the lack of data for continues GWs (i.e., non-detection) can be used to test modified gravity theories.

Continuous Gravitational Waves from Gravitars in Quadratic F (R) Modified GravityDownload

You can see the correspending GitHub repo here, which includes the code and figures in high quality.

The Formation and Coalescence of Binary Systems

Originally wrote in July 2022

This is actually a review paper not a research paper. I worked with Mustafa Mohammed, a close friend of mine, and under the supervision of Sama Nooh, a student from Sharkya STEM School. This is was during our 2022 membership in YSJ (short for Youth Science Journal, a student-led research organization). Our paper ranked first among all 21 papers written that year.

Binary systems are pairs of astronomical objects that stick together because of gravity. Mustafa and I compared the hypotheses for their formation, classified them into two categories based on their distance from each other (wide or close), and discussed their phases of coalescence (i.e., merging).

The Formation and Coalescence of Binary SystemsDownload
